awd_abstract_narration:
Tsunamis in the ocean and intense laser fiber optics are examples of waves whose speed of propagation depend on both the wave's wavelength and amplitude/intensity.  The coincidence of these two properties in media that support waves is not limited to the ocean and fibers but is ubiquitous in nature, the lab, and technology.  There is an emerging field of applied mathematics called dispersive hydrodynamics that explores the mathematical and physical ramifications of these two properties.  This project will develop new mathematical solutions and models of nonlinear, dispersive waves in a variety of physical environments.  The solutions will include solitons or solitary waves and dispersive shock waves, quintessential manifestations of waves whose speeds depend on wave amplitude and wavelength.  An in-house laboratory shallow water experiment will also be constructed to realize and test the physical implications of the developed mathematics.  Additional applications to fluid dynamics, nonlinear optics, and quantum fluids will be by-products of this research. Consequently, this project is truly interdisciplinary.

Dispersive hydrodynamics has emerged as a unified mathematical framework for the description of multiscale nonlinear wave phenomena in dispersive media.  Small-scale solitons/solitary waves and large-scale hydrodynamic waves (dispersive shock waves, rarefaction waves) are both solutions of nonlinear dispersive wave equations. This project weaves together research on integrable and nonintegrable dispersive partial differential equations, convex and nonconvex dispersive hydrodynamic systems, multidimensional waves, asymptotic analysis, and applications that include an in-house shallow water experiment.  While the mathematics of solitons and that of dispersive shock waves have been extensively developed in isolation, this project explores the rich and physically motivated set of new mathematical problems related to soliton propagation in dispersive hydrodynamic flows.  The scale separation inherent to solitons and dispersive hydrodynamic flows enables the asymptotic description of their interaction in a convenient and universal form in terms of a hyperbolic system of partial differential equations with a linearly degenerate field.  Extending and applying this description to nonconvex, multidimensional, and attractive dispersive hydrodynamic flows are the primary aims of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this award centered on the applied mathematics (modeling, analysis, numerical simulation, and experiment) of dispersive hydrodynamics in fluid dynamics and beyond.  Dispersive hydrodynamics encompass the evolution of multiscale wave solutions of nonlinear partial differential equations.  The physical waves modeled by these equations include solitary waves (or solitons), periodic waves, and dispersive shock waves, all of which are strongly influenced by the countervailing effects of wave amplitude/intensity and wavelength.  The research supported by this award has resulted in 16 peer-reviewed publication.

This research's intellectual merit is primarily comprised of 1) advances in nonlinear wave modulation theory for multidimensional media and media with non-convex flux or higher order dispersion and 2) modeling and experiments with applications in fluid dynamics.  Obtained modulation solutions describe the propagation of a truncated solitary wave from a channel into an open domain, the Russell-Mach reflection or expansion of a solitary wave from a compressive or expansive corner, respectively, the interaction of an oblique solitary wave with a mean field (rarefaction or dispersive shock wave). New, discontinuous modulation solutions were shown to correspond to traveling wave solutions of higher order dispersive equations consisting of a periodic traveling wave rapidly transitioning to another periodic traveling wave or constant.

Additionally, this award supported the fluid dynamics laboratory, the Dispersive Hydrodynamics Lab, in the Department of Applied Mathematics at CU Boulder, where a number of experiments on dispersive hydrodynamics were successfully designed, run, and analyzed.  These included the fission of solitary waves from a large disturbance, the generation of periodic waves from a boundary, and the interaction of a solitary wave and a periodic traveling wave resulting in the first observation of a new class of breathers.

The broader impacts of this research include training of students, outreach activities and public lectures, a research monograph, and a 6-month research program on the subject of dispersive hydrodynamics at the Isaac Newton Institute, Cambridge, UK.  Fifteen undergraduate students, eight PhD students, and one postdoctoral fellow participated in this research.  The experimental lab supported by this award inspires new applied mathematicians with accessible opportunities to contribute to nonlinear wave research through a concrete, visual application.  The lab also supported a number of outreach events, demos, and lab tours involving new undergraduate/graduate students as well as senior researchers.  The visibility of this research helped the PI become a CU Wizard.  For over three decades, the CU Wizards have entertained and informed children and their parents about the wonders of science. Once each month, from September through June, CU Wizards present a Saturday morning interactive show to the public.  Many of the students and the postdoc involved in this research participated in these outreach activities and two CU Wizards shows.

Looking to the future, much of the research supported by this award forms the basis of a book on dispersive hydrodynamics that is being co-authored by the PI.  This book will provide both an entry point and reference for new and established researchers in the field of dispersive hydrodynamics.  A direct outgrowth of the research supported by this award was a 6-month research program on dispersive hydrodynamics that took place July-December 2020 at the Isaac Newton Institute, Cambridge UK.  The PI of this award was the principal organizer of the research program, which consisted of five week-long conferences on various research themes as well as 115 in-residence participants who, along with conference participants, contributed over 250 seminars and lectures, as well as the mentoring of new researchers.  The book and research program indicate the growing appeal and interest in the research supported by this award.
